This file is a merged representation of the entire codebase, combined into a single document by Repomix.
The content has been processed where content has been formatted for parsing in markdown style, content has been compressed (code blocks are separated by ⋮---- delimiter).

# File Summary

## Purpose
This file contains a packed representation of the entire repository's contents.
It is designed to be easily consumable by AI systems for analysis, code review,
or other automated processes.

## File Format
The content is organized as follows:
1. This summary section
2. Repository information
3. Directory structure
4. Multiple file entries, each consisting of:
  a. A header with the file path (## File: path/to/file)
  b. The full contents of the file in a code block

## Usage Guidelines
- This file should be treated as read-only. Any changes should be made to the
  original repository files, not this packed version.
- When processing this file, use the file path to distinguish
  between different files in the repository.
- Be aware that this file may contain sensitive information. Handle it with
  the same level of security as you would the original repository.

## Notes
- Some files may have been excluded based on .gitignore rules and Repomix's configuration
- Binary files are not included in this packed representation. Please refer to the Repository Structure section for a complete list of file paths, including binary files
- Files matching patterns in .gitignore are excluded
- Files matching default ignore patterns are excluded
- Content has been formatted for parsing in markdown style
- Content has been compressed - code blocks are separated by ⋮---- delimiter
- Files are sorted by Git change count (files with more changes are at the bottom)

## Additional Info

# Files

## File: .repomix/bundles.json

## File: api.json
````json

API","version":"1.0.0"},"paths":{"/api":{"get":{"responses":{"200":{"description":"Success"}},"operationId":"getApi","tags":["system"],"parameters":[],"description":"Get API status"}},"/api/agents":{"get":{"responses":{"200":{"description":"List of all agents"}},"operationId":"getApiAgents","tags":["agents"],"parameters":[],"description":"Get all available agents"}},"/api/networks":{"get":{"responses":{"200":{"description":"List of all networks"}},"operationId":"getApiNetworks","tags":["networks"],"parameters":[],"description":"Get all available networks"}},"/api/networks/{networkId}":{"get":{"responses":{"200":{"description":"Network details"},"404":{"description":"Network not ID"}},"/api/networks/{networkId}/generate":{"post":{"responses":{"200":{"description":"Generated response"},"404":{"description":"Network not instructions","requestBody":{"required":true,"content":{"application/json":{"schema":{"type":"object","properties":{"instructions":{"type":"string","description":"New instructions for the analysis","content":{"application/json":{"schema":{"type":"object","properties":{"explanation":{"type":"string","description":"Detailed analysis of the ## File: CHANGELOG.md
````markdown
# Changelog

## [Unreleased]

## [0.1.1] - 2025-04-11

### Added

- Installed comprehensive AI package ecosystem:
  - **Mastra AI packages:**
    - @mastra/client-js (v0.1.16): Client-side SDK for Mastra integration
    - @mastra/core (v0.8.2): Core functionality for agent management
    - @mastra/loggers (v0.1.17): Logging utilities for Mastra agents
    - @mastra/memory (v0.2.9): Memory management for conversational agents
    - @mastra/pinecone (v0.2.7): Pinecone vector database integration
    - @mastra/upstash (v0.2.4): Upstash database integration
    - @mastra/vector-pinecone (v0.1.5): Vector operations with Pinecone
    - @mastra/voice-elevenlabs (v0.1.12): ElevenLabs voice integration
    - @mastra/voice-google (v0.1.12): Google voice integration
  - **@agentic ecosystem packages:**
    - @agentic/ai-sdk (v7.6.4): Core AI SDK functionality
    - @agentic/arxiv (v7.6.4): ArXiv research paper integration
    - @agentic/brave-search (v7.6.4): Brave search integration
    - @agentic/calculator (v7.6.4): Mathematical calculation capabilities
    - @agentic/core (v7.6.4): Core agent framework
    - @agentic/e2b (v7.6.4): E2B agent integration
    - @agentic/exa (v7.6.4): Exa search integration
    - @agentic/firecrawl (v7.6.4): Web crawling functionality
    - @agentic/genkit (v7.6.4): Generation toolkit
    - @agentic/google-custom-search (v7.6.4): Google Custom Search integration
    - @agentic/google-docs (v7.6.4): Google Docs integration
    - @agentic/google-drive (v7.6.4): Google Drive integration
    - @agentic/langchain (v7.6.4): LangChain integration
    - @agentic/llamaindex (v7.6.4): LlamaIndex integration
    - @agentic/mastra (v7.6.4): Mastra AI integration
    - @agentic/mcp (v7.6.4): Model Context Protocol integration
    - @agentic/stdlib (v7.6.4): Standard library for agent operations
    - @agentic/tavily (v7.6.4): Tavily search integration
    - @agentic/wikipedia (v7.6.4): Wikipedia integration
  - **AI SDK packages:**
    - @ai-sdk/google (v1.2.10): Google AI integration
    - @ai-sdk/google-vertex (v2.2.14): Google Vertex AI integration
    - @ai-sdk/provider (v1.1.2): Provider abstractions
    - @ai-sdk/provider-utils (v2.2.6): Utility functions for providers
  - **MCP integration:**
    - @modelcontextprotocol/sdk (v1.9.0): Model Context Protocol SDK
- Initialized Mastra with `pnpm dlx mastra@latest init`
- Added Mastra server packages to `serverExternalPackages` in Next.js config
- Created Weather API endpoint using Mastra agent
- Implemented server action `getWeatherInfo` for weather data
- Added Weather component with form for city input
- Set up API route for chat streaming with Mastra

### Changed

- Updated Next.js configuration to support Mastra integration
- Updated project version to 0.1.1

### Technical Details

- Configured `next.config.ts` to allow server-side external packages for Mastra
- Created a streaming API endpoint for chat responses
- Implemented server action for direct agent invocation
- Built React component with form data submission
- Integrated vector database capabilities through Pinecone (v5.1.1)
- Added support for LangChain (v0.3.21) and LangChain Community (v0.3.40)
- Set up integration with various AI providers through unified SDK interfaces
- Enabled voice capabilities through ElevenLabs and Google voice integrations

### Mastra Implementation Details

- **Core Setup (`/src/mastra/index.ts`):**
  - Configured Mastra instance with custom workflows, agents and logging
  - Centralized agent and workflow registration in a single export
- **Weather Agent (`/src/mastra/agents/index.ts`):**
  - Implemented a specialized weather assistant using Google's Gemini 1.5 Pro model
  - Defined detailed contextual instructions for consistent, accurate weather responses
  - Integrated with custom weather tool for real-time data retrieval
- **Custom Weather Tool (`/src/mastra/tools/index.ts`):**
  - Created a weather data retrieval tool using Open Meteo API
  - Implemented geocoding for location-to-coordinates conversion
  - Built comprehensive weather condition mapping for 30+ weather codes
  - Schema validation using Zod for type safety and input/output validation
- **Weather Workflow (`/src/mastra/workflows/index.ts`):**
  - Designed a multi-step workflow for advanced weather processing
  - Created an activity recommendation system based on weather conditions
  - Implemented structured output formatting with emojis and sectioned content

## [0.1.0] - 2025-04-11

### Initial Release

- Project scaffolding with Next.js 15.3.0
- Base configuration setup
````

## File: src/components/ui/carousel.tsx
````typescript
import useEmblaCarousel, {
  type UseEmblaCarouselType,
} from "embla-carousel-react"
import { ArrowLeft, ArrowRight } from "lucide-react"
⋮----
import { cn } from "@/lib/utils"
import { Button } from "@/components/ui/button"
⋮----
type CarouselApi = UseEmblaCarouselType[1]
type UseCarouselParameters = Parameters<typeof useEmblaCarousel>
type CarouselOptions = UseCarouselParameters[0]
type CarouselPlugin = UseCarouselParameters[1]
⋮----
type CarouselProps = {
  opts?: CarouselOptions
  plugins?: CarouselPlugin
  orientation?: "horizontal" | "vertical"
  setApi?: (api: CarouselApi) => void
}
⋮----
type CarouselContextProps = {
  carouselRef: ReturnType<typeof useEmblaCarousel>[0]
  api: ReturnType<typeof useEmblaCarousel>[1]
  scrollPrev: () => void
  scrollNext: () => void
  canScrollPrev: boolean
  canScrollNext: boolean
} & CarouselProps
⋮----
function useCarousel()
````

## File: src/components/ui/chart.tsx
````typescript
import { cn } from "@/lib/utils"
⋮----
// Format: { THEME_NAME: CSS_SELECTOR }
⋮----
export type ChartConfig = {
  [k in string]: {
    label?: React.ReactNode
    icon?: React.ComponentType
  } & (
    | { color?: string; theme?: never }
    | { color?: never; theme: Record<keyof typeof THEMES, string> }
  )
}
⋮----
type ChartContextProps = {
  config: ChartConfig
}
⋮----
function useChart()
⋮----
function ChartContainer({
  id,
  className,
  children,
  config,
  ...props
}: React.ComponentProps<"div"> & {
  config: ChartConfig
  children: React.ComponentProps<
    typeof RechartsPrimitive.ResponsiveContainer
  >["children"]
})
⋮----
className=
⋮----
<div className=
⋮----
// Helper to extract item config from a payload.

## File: src/config/theme.ts

## File: src/content/docs/api-reference/agent/page.mdx
````
---
title: Agent API Reference
description: Complete API reference for creating and managing AI agents.
---

# Agent API Reference

The Agent API allows you to create, configure, and manage AI agents in your applications.

## Creating an Agent

### `createAgent`

Creates a new AI agent with the specified configuration.

```typescript
interface AgentConfig {
  name: string;
  description?: string;
  model: {
    name: string;
    temperature?: number;
    maxTokens?: number;
  };
  capabilities: string[];
  memory?: MemoryConfig;
}

const agent = await client.createAgent({
  name: "support-agent",
  description: "Customer support agent",
  model: {
    name: "gpt-4",
    temperature: 0.7,
  },
  capabilities: ["chat", "knowledge-base"],
});
```

### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Required | Description |
|-----------|------|----------|-------------|
| name | string | Yes | Unique identifier for the agent |
| description | string | No | Human-readable description |
| model | ModelConfig | Yes | AI model configuration |
| capabilities | string[] | Yes | List of agent capabilities |
| memory | MemoryConfig | No | Memory system configuration |

### Response

```typescript
interface Agent {
  id: string;
  name: string;
  status: "active" | "inactive" | "error";
  created: string;
  lastActive: string;
  capabilities: string[];
  config: AgentConfig;
}
```

## Managing Agents

### `listAgents`

Retrieves a list of all agents in your project.

```typescript
const agents = await client.listAgents({
  status: "active",
  limit: 10,
  offset: 0,
});
```

### `updateAgent`

Updates an existing agent's configuration.

```typescript
await client.updateAgent(agentId, {
  description: "Updated description",
  model: {
    temperature: 0.8,
  },
});
```

### `deleteAgent`

Deletes an agent and its associated resources.

```typescript
await client.deleteAgent(agentId);
```

## Agent Interactions

### `sendMessage`

Sends a message to an agent and receives a response.

```typescript
const response = await agent.sendMessage({
  content: "Hello, how can I help?",
  type: "text",
  context: {
    userId: "user-123",
    sessionId: "session-456",
  },
});
```

### `streamResponse`

Streams an agent's response in real-time.

```typescript
const stream = await agent.streamResponse({
  content: "Generate a long report",
  onToken: (token) => {
    console.log("Received token:", token);
  },
});
```

## Webhooks

### `registerWebhook`

Registers a webhook to receive agent events.

```typescript
await client.registerWebhook({
  url: "https://api.yourdomain.com/webhooks/agent",
  events: ["message.created", "agent.status"],
  secret: process.env.WEBHOOK_SECRET,
});
```

## Error Handling

```typescript
try {
  const agent = await client.createAgent(config);
} catch (error) {
  if (error instanceof AgentError) {
    console.error("Agent creation failed:", error.message);
    // Handle specific error cases
    switch (error.code) {
      case "invalid_config":
        // Handle invalid configuration
        break;
      case "quota_exceeded":
        // Handle quota issues
        break;
    }
  }
}
```

## Best Practices

1. **Error Handling**
   - Always implement proper error handling
   - Use type-safe error handling with discriminated unions
   - Handle rate limiting and retry scenarios

2. **Security**
   - Keep API keys secure
   - Validate all inputs
   - Use HTTPS for webhook endpoints

3. **Performance**
   - Use streaming for long responses
   - Implement proper connection handling
   - Consider rate limits in your design

<Callout type="warning">
  Never expose your API keys in client-side code or version control systems.
</Callout>

## Rate Limits

| Operation | Rate Limit |
|-----------|------------|
| Create Agent | 10/minute |
| Send Message | 60/minute |
| Update Agent | 30/minute |
| Delete Agent | 10/minute |

## Next Steps

- [Memory API Reference](/docs/api-reference/memory)
- [Agent Tutorial](/docs/tutorials/creating-agents)
- [Agent Examples](/docs/examples/agents)
````

## File: src/content/docs/api-reference/cli.mdx
````
---
title: "CLI Reference"
description: "Command Line Interface reference for DeanMachines"
---

# CLI Reference

## Overview

The DeanMachines CLI provides a powerful command-line interface for managing your agents, networks, and deployments.

## Installation

```bash
npm install -g deanmachines-cli
```

## Usage

```bash
deanmachines [command] [options]
```

## Commands

### Agent Management

```bash
deanmachines agent create [name]
deanmachines agent list
deanmachines agent delete [name]
```

### Network Management

```bash
deanmachines network create [name]
deanmachines network list
deanmachines network delete [name]
```

### Deployment

```bash
deanmachines deploy [environment]
deanmachines deploy status
deanmachines deploy rollback
```

## Configuration

```bash
deanmachines config set [key] [value]
deanmachines config get [key]
deanmachines config list
```

## Help

```bash
deanmachines help
deanmachines [command] --help
```
````

## File: src/content/docs/api-reference/cli/page.mdx
````
---
title: "CLI Reference"
description: "Command Line Interface reference for DeanMachines"
---

# CLI Reference

## Overview

The DeanMachines CLI is a powerful command-line interface that allows you to manage your agents, networks, and deployments. It provides a consistent interface for interacting with the DeanMachines platform from your terminal.

## Installation

```bash
npm install -g deanmachines-cli
```

## Usage

```bash
deanmachines [command] [options]
```

Run `deanmachines --help` for a list of all available commands.

## Commands

### Agent Management

```bash
deanmachines agent create [name] [options]
deanmachines agent list [options]
deanmachines agent delete [name] [options]
deanmachines agent update [name] [options]
```

#### Options

```bash
--description, -d <description>  Agent description
--type, -t <type>               Agent type (node, python, etc.)
--version, -v <version>         Agent version
--config, -c <path>            Path to configuration file
```

### Network Management

```bash
deanmachines network create [name] [options]
deanmachines network list [options]
deanmachines network delete [name] [options]
deanmachines network update [name] [options]
```

#### Options

```bash
--type, -t <type>               Network type (local, distributed, cloud)
--protocol, -p <protocol>      Network protocol (tcp, udp, etc.)
--encryption, -e <level>       Encryption level
--nodes, -n <count>           Number of nodes
```

### Deployment

```bash
deanmachines deploy [environment] [options]
deanmachines deploy status [options]
deanmachines deploy rollback [options]
```

#### Options

```bash
--environment, -e <env>    Environment name
--version, -v <version>   Version to deploy
--force, -f               Force deployment
--dry-run                 Show what would be deployed
```

### Configuration

```bash
deanmachines config set [key] [value]
deanmachines config get [key]
deanmachines config list
deanmachines config export [path]
```

### Help

```bash
deanmachines help
deanmachines [command] --help
```

## Environment Variables

You can override CLI configuration using environment variables:

```bash
# Core settings
DEANMACHINES_API_KEY=your_api_key
DEANMACHINES_API_ENDPOINT=https://api.deanmachines.com

# Agent settings
DEANMACHINES_AGENT_TIMEOUT=30000
DEANMACHINES_AGENT_MAX_CONCURRENCY=5

# Network settings
DEANMACHINES_NETWORK_TYPE=distributed
DEANMACHINES_NETWORK_PROTOCOL=tcp
```

## Best Practices

1. Use meaningful names for agents and networks
2. Keep configuration in version control
3. Use environment variables for sensitive information
4. Regularly update CLI to latest version
5. Use dry-run before major deployments
6. Document all custom configurations

## Troubleshooting

Common issues and solutions:

1. **Authentication Issues**
   - Check your API key
   - Verify API endpoint
   - Check network connectivity

2. **Deployment Failures**
   - Check environment status
   - Review deployment logs
   - Verify configuration

3. **Network Connectivity**
   - Check firewall rules
   - Verify network configuration
   - Test connectivity

## Version History

- 1.0.0 - Initial release
- 1.1.0 - Added network management
- 1.2.0 - Added deployment commands
- 1.3.0 - Added configuration management
````

## File: src/content/docs/api-reference/deployment.mdx
````
---
title: Deployment API Reference
description: Complete API reference for deploying and managing AI applications in production.
---

# Deployment API Reference

The Deployment API provides tools and endpoints for deploying, scaling, and managing AI applications in production environments.

## Environment Configuration

### Create Environment

```typescript
interface EnvironmentConfig {
  name: string;
  type: 'development' | 'staging' | 'production';
  region: string;
  resources: {
    compute: {
      type: string;
      size: string;
      autoscaling?: {
        min: number;
        max: number;
        targetCPU: number;
      };
    };
    memory: {
      size: string;
      type: 'standard' | 'high-memory';
    };
    storage: {
      size: string;
      type: 'ssd' | 'premium-ssd';
    };
  };
}

const env = await client.createEnvironment({
  name: 'prod-us-east',
  type: 'production',
  region: 'us-east-1',
  resources: {
    compute: {
      type: 'standard',
      size: '2xlarge',
      autoscaling: {
        min: 2,
        max: 10,
        targetCPU: 70
      }
    },
    memory: {
      size: '16Gi',
      type: 'high-memory'
    },
    storage: {
      size: '100Gi',
      type: 'premium-ssd'
    }
  }
});
```

## Deployment Operations

### Deploy Application

```typescript
interface DeploymentConfig {
  environment: string;
  version: string;
  agents: {
    id: string;
    replicas: number;
    resources: ResourceConfig;
  }[];
  networking: {
    ingress?: {
      domain: string;
      tls: boolean;
    };
    vpc?: {
      id: string;
      subnets: string[];
    };
  };
  monitoring: {
    metrics: boolean;
    logging: boolean;
    tracing: boolean;
  };
}

const deployment = await client.deploy({
  environment: 'prod-us-east',
  version: '1.0.0',
  agents: [
    {
      id: 'support-agent',
      replicas: 3,
      resources: {
        cpu: '2',
        memory: '4Gi'
      }
    }
  ],
  networking: {
    ingress: {
      domain: 'api.deanmachines.com',
      tls: true
    }
  },
  monitoring: {
    metrics: true,
    logging: true,
    tracing: true
  }
});
```

## Scaling Operations

### Configure Autoscaling

```typescript
await client.configureScaling('prod-us-east', {
  metrics: ['cpu', 'memory', 'requests'],
  rules: [
    {
      metric: 'cpu',
      target: 70,
      minReplicas: 2,
      maxReplicas: 10
    },
    {
      metric: 'requests',
      target: 1000,
      minReplicas: 3,
      maxReplicas: 15
    }
  ]
});
```

## Monitoring & Observability

### Configure Monitoring

```typescript
interface MonitoringConfig {
  metrics: {
    provider: 'prometheus' | 'datadog';
    scrapeInterval: string;
    retention: string;
  };
  logging: {
    provider: 'elasticsearch' | 'cloudwatch';
    retention: string;
    indexes: string[];
  };
  alerting: {
    channels: string[];
    rules: AlertRule[];
  };
}

await client.configureMonitoring({
  metrics: {
    provider: 'prometheus',
    scrapeInterval: '15s',
    retention: '30d'
  },
  logging: {
    provider: 'elasticsearch',
    retention: '90d',
    indexes: ['app-logs', 'agent-logs']
  },
  alerting: {
    channels: ['slack', 'email'],
    rules: [
      {
        name: 'high-error-rate',
        condition: 'error_rate > 0.01',
        duration: '5m',
        severity: 'critical'
      }
    ]
  }
});
```

## Infrastructure Management

### Resource Management

```typescript
interface ResourceUpdate {
  compute?: {
    size?: string;
    autoscaling?: AutoscalingConfig;
  };
  memory?: {
    size?: string;
  };
  storage?: {
    size?: string;
  };
}

await client.updateResources('prod-us-east', {
  compute: {
    size: '4xlarge',
    autoscaling: {
      min: 4,
      max: 20
    }
  },
  memory: {
    size: '32Gi'
  }
});
```

## Security & Compliance

### Configure Security

```typescript
interface SecurityConfig {
  network: {
    encryption: boolean;
    firewalls: FirewallRule[];
    allowedIPs: string[];
  };
  authentication: {
    type: 'jwt' | 'oauth2';
    provider?: string;
    config: Record<string, unknown>;
  };
  compliance: {
    audit: boolean;
    retention: string;
    encryption: {
      atRest: boolean;
      inTransit: boolean;
    };
  };
}

await client.configureSecurity({
  network: {
    encryption: true,
    firewalls: [
      {
        name: 'allow-api',
        ports: [443],
        sources: ['0.0.0.0/0']
      }
    ]
  },
  authentication: {
    type: 'oauth2',
    provider: 'auth0',
    config: {
      domain: 'your-domain.auth0.com'
    }
  },
  compliance: {
    audit: true,
    retention: '365d',
    encryption: {
      atRest: true,
      inTransit: true
    }
  }
});
```

## Error Handling

```typescript
try {
  await client.deploy(config);
} catch (error) {
  if (error instanceof DeploymentError) {
    switch (error.code) {
      case 'insufficient_resources':
        await client.requestResourceIncrease();
        break;
      case 'invalid_configuration':
        await client.validateConfig(config);
        break;
    }
  }
  throw error;
}
```

## Best Practices

1. **Deployment Strategy**
   - Use blue-green deployments
   - Implement proper health checks
   - Configure appropriate resource limits
   - Monitor deployment metrics

2. **Security**
   - Enable encryption in transit
   - Configure network policies
   - Implement access controls
   - Regular security audits

3. **Monitoring**
   - Set up comprehensive monitoring
   - Configure appropriate alerts
   - Implement proper logging
   - Monitor resource usage

<Callout type="warning">
  Always test deployments in a staging environment before deploying to production.
</Callout>

## Rate Limits

| Operation | Rate Limit |
|-----------|------------|
| Deployments | 10/hour |
| Configuration Updates | 30/hour |
| Resource Scaling | 20/hour |
| Security Updates | 10/hour |

## Next Steps

- [CI/CD Integration](/docs/deployment/ci-cd)
- [Monitoring Setup](/docs/deployment/monitoring)
- [Security Configuration](/docs/deployment/security)
````

## File: src/content/docs/api-reference/memory.mdx
````
---
title: Memory API Reference
description: Complete API reference for managing AI agent memory systems.
---

# Memory API Reference

The Memory API enables sophisticated memory management and context storage for AI agents.

## Memory Types

### Short-Term Memory

```typescript
interface ShortTermMemoryConfig {
  capacity: number;
  ttl: string;  // Time-to-live duration
  strategy: 'fifo' | 'lru';
}

const memory = await client.createMemory({
  type: 'short-term',
  config: {
    capacity: 100,
    ttl: '1h',
    strategy: 'lru'
  }
});
```

### Long-Term Memory

```typescript
interface LongTermMemoryConfig {
  storage: 'postgres' | 'redis' | 'vector';
  indexing: {
    enabled: boolean;
    dimensions?: number;
    similarity?: 'cosine' | 'euclidean';
  };
}

const persistentMemory = await client.createMemory({
  type: 'long-term',
  config: {
    storage: 'postgres',
    indexing: {
      enabled: true,
      dimensions: 1536,
      similarity: 'cosine'
    }
  }
});
```

## Memory Operations

### Store Data

```typescript
interface MemoryEntry {
  key: string;
  value: unknown;
  metadata?: Record<string, unknown>;
  tags?: string[];
  ttl?: string;
}

await memory.store({
  key: 'conversation:123',
  value: {
    messages: [],
    context: { topic: 'support' }
  },
  tags: ['conversation', 'support'],
  ttl: '24h'
});
```

### Retrieve Data

```typescript
const data = await memory.retrieve('conversation:123');
const taggedData = await memory.retrieveByTags(['conversation']);
const vectorData = await memory.searchSimilar('query text', {
  limit: 5,
  threshold: 0.8
});
```

### Update Data

```typescript
await memory.update('conversation:123', {
  messages: [...existingMessages, newMessage]
});

// Partial updates
await memory.patch('conversation:123', {
  'messages[-1]': newMessage
});
```

### Delete Data

```typescript
await memory.delete('conversation:123');
await memory.deleteByTags(['temporary']);
await memory.clear(); // Clear all data
```

## Memory Events

### Subscribe to Changes

```typescript
memory.on('change', (event) => {
  console.log('Memory changed:', event);
});

memory.on('expire', (key) => {
  console.log('Entry expired:', key);
});
```

## Batch Operations

### Bulk Store

```typescript
await memory.bulkStore([
  { key: 'user:1', value: userData1 },
  { key: 'user:2', value: userData2 }
]);
```

### Bulk Retrieve

```typescript
const entries = await memory.bulkRetrieve([
  'user:1',
  'user:2'
]);
```

## Memory Analytics

### Usage Statistics

```typescript
const stats = await memory.getStats();
// {
//   totalEntries: 1000,
//   totalSize: "500MB",
//   avgAccessTime: "50ms"
// }
```

### Memory Health

```typescript
const health = await memory.checkHealth();
// {
//   status: "healthy",
//   issues: [],
//   lastOptimization: "2024-04-07T..."
// }
```

## Error Handling

```typescript
try {
  await memory.store(entry);
} catch (error) {
  if (error instanceof MemoryError) {
    switch (error.code) {
      case 'capacity_exceeded':
        await memory.optimize();
        break;
      case 'storage_unavailable':
        await memory.reconnect();
        break;
    }
  }
  throw error;
}
```

## Best Practices

1. **Memory Management**
   - Set appropriate TTL values
   - Implement cleanup strategies
   - Monitor memory usage
   - Use batch operations for bulk data

2. **Performance**
   - Index frequently accessed data
   - Use appropriate storage backends
   - Implement caching strategies
   - Monitor access patterns

3. **Data Security**
   - Encrypt sensitive data
   - Implement access controls
   - Regular backups
   - Audit access logs

<Callout type="info">
  Choose memory types based on your specific use case requirements for persistence, speed, and scale.
</Callout>

## Rate Limits

| Operation | Rate Limit |
|-----------|------------|
| Store | 1000/minute |
| Retrieve | 2000/minute |
| Update | 500/minute |
| Delete | 200/minute |

## Next Steps

- [Network API Reference](/docs/api-reference/network)
- [Memory Management Guide](/docs/guides/memory-management)
- [Memory Examples](/docs/examples/memory)
````

## File: src/content/docs/api-reference/network.mdx
````
---
title: Network API Reference
description: Complete API reference for managing AI agent networks and communication.
---

# Network API Reference

The Network API enables creating and managing networks of cooperating AI agents.

## Network Creation

### Create Network

```typescript
interface NetworkConfig {
  name: string;
  description?: string;
  topology: 'mesh' | 'star' | 'hierarchical';
  maxAgents: number;
  protocol: {
    type: 'grpc' | 'websocket' | 'http';
    options?: Record<string, unknown>;
  };
}

const network = await client.createNetwork({
  name: 'analysis-network',
  topology: 'hierarchical',
  maxAgents: 10,
  protocol: {
    type: 'grpc',
    options: {
      keepAlive: true,
      timeout: '30s'
    }
  }
});
```

## Agent Management

### Add Agents

```typescript
interface AgentNode {
  agentId: string;
  role: string;
  connections: string[];  // Array of agent IDs to connect to
  priority?: number;      // Priority in hierarchical networks
}

await network.addAgent({
  agentId: 'agent-123',
  role: 'analyzer',
  connections: ['agent-456', 'agent-789'],
  priority: 1
});
```

### Remove Agents

```typescript
await network.removeAgent('agent-123', {
  gracePeriod: '5s',
  reassignConnections: true
});
```

## Communication

### Message Routing

```typescript
interface NetworkMessage {
  from: string;
  to: string | string[];
  content: unknown;
  metadata: {
    priority: number;
    ttl: string;
    trace?: string;
  };
}

await network.sendMessage({
  from: 'agent-123',
  to: 'agent-456',
  content: {
    type: 'analysis_request',
    data: { /* ... */ }
  },
  metadata: {
    priority: 1,
    ttl: '30s'
  }
});
```

### Broadcast Messages

```typescript
await network.broadcast({
  from: 'agent-123',
  content: {
    type: 'status_update',
    status: 'ready'
  },
  metadata: {
    priority: 2,
    ttl: '10s'
  }
});
```

## Network Topology

### Update Topology

```typescript
await network.updateTopology({
  type: 'mesh',
  connections: [
    { from: 'agent-1', to: ['agent-2', 'agent-3'] },
    { from: 'agent-2', to: ['agent-3', 'agent-4'] }
  ]
});
```

### Network Analysis

```typescript
const analysis = await network.analyze();
// {
//   nodes: number;
//   connections: number;
//   avgLatency: string;
//   bottlenecks: string[];
// }
```

## Monitoring

### Network Health

```typescript
const health = await network.checkHealth({
  timeout: '5s',
  checkConnections: true
});
```

### Network Metrics

```typescript
const metrics = await network.getMetrics({
  timeframe: '1h',
  resolution: '1m'
});
```

## Error Handling

```typescript
try {
  await network.sendMessage(message);
} catch (error) {
  if (error instanceof NetworkError) {
    switch (error.code) {
      case 'agent_unavailable':
        await network.rebalance();
        break;
      case 'connection_failed':
        await network.reconnect(message.to);
        break;
    }
  }
  throw error;
}
```

## Load Balancing

### Configure Load Balancer

```typescript
await network.configureLoadBalancing({
  strategy: 'least_loaded',
  metrics: ['cpu', 'memory', 'queue_length'],
  updateInterval: '10s',
  thresholds: {
    cpu: 80,
    memory: 85,
    queue_length: 100
  }
});
```

## Best Practices

1. **Network Design**
   - Choose appropriate topology
   - Plan for scalability
   - Implement proper error handling
   - Monitor network health

2. **Performance**
   - Use efficient message formats
   - Implement message prioritization
   - Configure appropriate timeouts
   - Monitor network latency

3. **Security**
   - Implement authentication
   - Encrypt network traffic
   - Monitor for anomalies
   - Regular security audits

<Callout type="warning">
  Always implement proper error handling and recovery mechanisms in distributed networks.
</Callout>

## Rate Limits

| Operation | Rate Limit |
|-----------|------------|
| Messages | 1000/minute/agent |
| Topology Changes | 10/minute |
| Agent Addition/Removal | 50/minute |
| Broadcasts | 100/minute |

## Next Steps

- [Deployment API Reference](/docs/api-reference/deployment)
- [Network Architecture Guide](/docs/guides/network-architecture)
- [Network Examples](/docs/examples/networks)
````

## File: src/content/docs/core-concepts/agent-networks.mdx
````
---
title: Agent Networks
description: Learn how to create and manage networks of cooperating AI agents.
---

# Agent Networks

Agent networks allow multiple AI agents to work together, share resources, and coordinate to solve complex problems.

## Network Architecture

### Basic Network Structure

```typescript
import { createNetwork } from '@deanmachines/core'

const network = createNetwork({
  name: 'CustomNetwork',
  topology: 'mesh', // or 'star', 'hierarchical'
  coordination: 'distributed',
})
```

### Network Roles

Agents can take different roles in a network:

- **Coordinator**: Manages task distribution and workflow
- **Specialist**: Handles specific types of tasks
- **Monitor**: Oversees network health and performance
- **Gateway**: Interfaces with external systems

## Creating Agent Networks

### Basic Network Setup

```typescript
// Create specialist agents
const dataAgent = createAgent({
  name: 'DataProcessor',
  capabilities: ['dataProcessing'],
})

const nlpAgent = createAgent({
  name: 'LanguageProcessor',
  capabilities: ['nlp'],
})

// Create and configure network
const network = createNetwork()
  .addAgent(dataAgent)
  .addAgent(nlpAgent)
  .setCoordinator(coordinatorAgent)
```

### Advanced Configuration

```typescript
const network = createNetwork({
  name: 'AdvancedNetwork',
  config: {
    loadBalancing: true,
    faultTolerance: {
      enabled: true,
      strategy: 'failover',
    },
    scaling: {
      min: 2,
      max: 10,
      metric: 'load',
    },
  },
})
```

## Communication Patterns

### Direct Communication

```typescript
// Agent-to-agent communication
await sourceAgent.sendMessage(targetAgent, {
  type: 'request',
  payload: { task: 'analyze_data' },
})

// Handle responses
targetAgent.onMessage(async (message, sender) => {
  if (message.type === 'request') {
    const result = await processRequest(message.payload)
    return { type: 'response', payload: result }
  }
})
```

### Broadcast Communication

```typescript
// Send to all agents in network
await network.broadcast({
  type: 'notification',
  payload: { status: 'system_update' },
})

// Handle broadcasts
agent.onBroadcast(async (message, network) => {
  await handleSystemUpdate(message.payload)
})
```

## Task Distribution

### Work Assignment

```typescript
// Coordinator assigns tasks
network.onTask(async (task) => {
  const availableAgents = await network.getAvailableAgents()
  const bestAgent = selectBestAgent(availableAgents, task)

  await network.assignTask(bestAgent, task)
})

// Agents handle assigned tasks
agent.onTask(async (task, context) => {
  const result = await processTask(task)
  await context.network.reportCompletion(task.id, result)
})
```

### Load Balancing

```typescript
const network = createNetwork({
  loadBalancing: {
    strategy: 'round-robin', // or 'least-loaded', 'capability-based'
    metrics: ['cpu', 'memory', 'queue_length'],
    updateInterval: '1m',
  },
})
```

## State Management

### Network State

```typescript
// Get network status
const status = await network.getStatus()

// Monitor state changes
network.onStateChange((newState, oldState) => {
  logStateChange(newState, oldState)
  adjustResources(newState)
})
```

### Agent State Synchronization

```typescript
// Share state updates
await agent.syncState({
  status: 'processing',
  currentTask: taskId,
  load: calculateLoad(),
})

// React to state changes
agent.onPeerStateChange((peer, newState) => {
  updateLocalView(peer, newState)
})
```

## Error Handling

### Network-Level Errors

```typescript
network.onError(async (error, context) => {
  if (error.type === 'agent_failure') {
    await handleAgentFailure(error.agentId)
  } else if (error.type === 'communication_error') {
    await retryConnection(error.source, error.target)
  }
})
```

### Fault Tolerance

```typescript
const network = createNetwork({
  faultTolerance: {
    autoRecover: true,
    maxRetries: 3,
    backoff: {
      initial: 1000,
      multiplier: 2,
      max: 30000,
    },
  },
})
```

## Monitoring and Analytics

### Performance Metrics

```typescript
// Collect network metrics
const metrics = await network.getMetrics({
  timeframe: 'last_hour',
  include: ['latency', 'throughput', 'error_rate'],
})

// Set up monitoring
network.monitor({
  interval: '1m',
  metrics: ['cpu', 'memory', 'communication'],
  alerts: {
    highLatency: { threshold: 1000, action: alertOps },
    errorSpike: { threshold: 0.05, action: notifyAdmin },
  },
})
```

## Best Practices

### Network Design

- Keep networks focused on related tasks
- Implement proper error handling
- Use appropriate communication patterns
- Monitor network health

### Performance

- Optimize message payload size
- Use efficient routing strategies
- Implement caching where appropriate
- Balance load across agents

### Security

- Authenticate agent communications
- Encrypt sensitive data
- Implement access controls
- Monitor for unusual behavior

<Callout>
  Complex networks may require careful monitoring and tuning. Start with simple topologies and expand based on needs.
</Callout>

## Advanced Topics

- [Custom Network Topologies](/docs/advanced-features/network-topologies)
- [Scaling Strategies](/docs/advanced-features/network-scaling)
- [Custom Protocols](/docs/advanced-features/network-protocols)
- [Network Security](/docs/advanced-features/network-security)
````

## File: src/content/docs/core-concepts/agents.mdx
````
---
title: AI Agents
description: Understanding AI agents, their capabilities, and how to build them effectively.
---

# AI Agents

AI agents are autonomous software entities that can perceive their environment, make decisions, and take actions to achieve specific goals.

## Agent Architecture

### Core Components

Every deanmachines AI agent consists of three main components:

1. **Perception System**: Processes inputs and understands context
2. **Decision Engine**: Analyzes situations and determines actions
3. **Action System**: Executes decisions and interacts with the environment

```typescript
interface AgentConfig {
  name: string;
  description: string;
  capabilities: Capability[];
  modelConfig?: ModelConfig;
  memory?: MemoryConfig;
}
```

## Agent Capabilities

Agents can be enhanced with various capabilities:

### Built-in Capabilities

- **Natural Language Processing**: Understanding and generating human language
- **Memory Management**: Maintaining context and learning from interactions
- **Task Planning**: Breaking down complex goals into actionable steps
- **Error Handling**: Graceful handling of exceptions and edge cases

### Optional Capabilities

- **API Integration**: Connecting with external services and data sources
- **File Processing**: Handling various file formats and data types
- **Image Analysis**: Processing and understanding visual information
- **Code Generation**: Creating and modifying code programmatically

## Creating Agents

### Basic Agent Creation

```typescript
import { createAgent } from '@deanmachines/core'

const agent = createAgent({
  name: 'SimpleAgent',
  description: 'A basic agent with core capabilities',
  capabilities: ['chat', 'memory'],
})
```

### Advanced Configuration

```typescript
const agent = createAgent({
  name: 'AdvancedAgent',
  description: 'An agent with advanced capabilities',
  capabilities: ['chat', 'memory', 'planning'],
  modelConfig: {
    type: 'gpt-4',
    temperature: 0.7,
    maxTokens: 2000,
  },
  memory: {
    type: 'conversational',
    ttl: '24h',
    storage: 'redis',
  },
})
```

## Agent Lifecycle

### 1. Initialization

```typescript
await agent.init({
  loadState: true,  // Load previous state
  warmup: true,     // Warm up ML models
})
```

### 2. Event Handling

```typescript
// Handle incoming messages
agent.onMessage(async (message, context) => {
  // Process message
  return response
})

// Handle errors
agent.onError((error) => {
  console.error('Agent error:', error)
})
```

### 3. State Management

```typescript
// Save agent state
await agent.saveState()

// Load agent state
await agent.loadState()

// Reset agent
await agent.reset()
```

## Best Practices

### 1. Agent Design

- Keep agents focused on specific tasks
- Use appropriate capabilities for the task
- Implement proper error handling
- Monitor agent performance

### 2. Memory Usage

- Configure appropriate TTL for memory
- Clean up unused memory
- Use efficient storage solutions
- Implement memory limitations

### 3. Security

- Validate all inputs
- Implement rate limiting
- Use secure communication channels
- Follow least privilege principle

## Examples

### Customer Service Agent

```typescript
const customerAgent = createAgent({
  name: 'CustomerSupport',
  description: 'Handles customer inquiries and support tickets',
  capabilities: [
    'chat',
    'memory',
    'ticketing',
    'knowledgeBase',
  ],
})

customerAgent.onMessage(async (message, context) => {
  // Analyze customer intent
  const intent = await customerAgent.analyzeIntent(message)

  // Access knowledge base
  const relevant = await customerAgent.searchKnowledge(intent)

  // Generate response
  return await customerAgent.generateResponse(message, relevant)
})
```

### Data Processing Agent

```typescript
const dataAgent = createAgent({
  name: 'DataProcessor',
  description: 'Processes and analyzes data files',
  capabilities: [
    'fileProcessing',
    'dataAnalysis',
    'visualization',
  ],
})

dataAgent.onFile(async (file, context) => {
  // Process file
  const data = await dataAgent.processFile(file)

  // Analyze data
  const analysis = await dataAgent.analyzeData(data)

  // Generate visualizations
  return await dataAgent.createVisualizations(analysis)
})
```

## Advanced Topics

- [Agent Networks](/docs/core-concepts/agent-networks)
- [Custom Capabilities](/docs/advanced-features/custom-capabilities)
- [Performance Optimization](/docs/advanced-features/performance)
- [Testing Strategies](/docs/testing/agents)

<Callout type="warning">
  Ensure your agents handle rate limits and API quotas appropriately when integrating with external services.
</Callout>
````

## File: src/content/docs/core-concepts/deployment.mdx
````
---
title: Deployment
description: Learn how to deploy and scale your AI applications in production environments.
---

# Deployment

Learn how to deploy your deanmachines AI applications to production environments securely and efficiently.

## Deployment Options

### Cloud Providers

We support deployment across major cloud providers:

- **AWS**: Lambda, ECS, and EKS
- **Google Cloud**: Cloud Run, GKE
- **Azure**: Azure Functions, AKS
- **Custom**: Self-hosted infrastructure

## Quick Deploy

### Using CLI

```bash
# Initialize deployment configuration
dm deploy init

# Deploy to development
dm deploy dev

# Deploy to production
dm deploy prod --confirm
```

### Using GitHub Actions

```yaml
name: Deploy AI Application

on:
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
      - uses: deanmachines/deploy-action@v1
        with:
          environment: production
          api-key: ${{ secrets.DEANMACHINES_API_KEY }}
```

## Configuration

### Basic Configuration

```typescript
// deanmachines.config.ts
export default {
  name: 'my-ai-app',
  runtime: 'node18',
  region: 'us-east-1',
  scaling: {
    minInstances: 1,
    maxInstances: 10,
  },
}
```

### Advanced Configuration

```typescript
export default {
  name: 'my-ai-app',
  runtime: 'node18',
  regions: ['us-east-1', 'eu-west-1'],
  scaling: {
    minInstances: 1,
    maxInstances: 10,
    targetCPUUtilization: 70,
    scaleDownDelay: '10m',
  },
  networking: {
    vpc: true,
    privateSubnets: true,
    natGateways: 1,
  },
  security: {
    encryption: {
      atRest: true,
      inTransit: true,
    },
    accessControl: {
      rbac: true,
      serviceAccounts: true,
    },
  },
}
```

## Infrastructure as Code

### Terraform Example

```hcl
module "deanmachines_app" {
  source  = "deanmachines/app/aws"
  version = "1.0.0"

  name        = "my-ai-app"
  environment = "production"

  vpc_config = {
    cidr = "10.0.0.0/16"
    azs  = ["us-east-1a", "us-east-1b"]
  }

  scaling_config = {
    min_size     = 1
    max_size     = 10
    target_cpu   = 70
  }
}
```

### Pulumi Example

```typescript
import * as deanmachines from "@pulumi/deanmachines"

const app = new deanmachines.App("my-ai-app", {
  environment: "production",
  scaling: {
    minInstances: 1,
    maxInstances: 10,
  },
  networking: {
    vpc: true,
    privateSubnets: true,
  },
})
```

## Container Deployment

### Docker Configuration

```dockerfile
FROM deanmachines/runtime:node18

WORKDIR /app
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm install

COPY . .
RUN npm run build

ENV NODE_ENV=production
EXPOSE 3000

CMD ["npm", "start"]
```

### Kubernetes Deployment

```yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: ai-app
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: ai-app
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: ai-app
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: ai-app
        image: my-registry/ai-app:latest
        env:
          - name: DEANMACHINES_API_KEY
            valueFrom:
              secretKeyRef:
                name: ai-secrets
                key: api-key
        resources:
          requests:
            memory: "512Mi"
            cpu: "250m"
          limits:
            memory: "1Gi"
            cpu: "500m"
```

## Environment Management

### Environment Variables

```bash
# .env.production
DEANMACHINES_API_KEY=your_api_key
DEANMACHINES_ENVIRONMENT=production
DEANMACHINES_REGION=us-east-1
MEMORY_STORAGE_TYPE=redis
REDIS_URL=redis://cache.example.com
```

### Secrets Management

```typescript
import { createSecretsManager } from '@deanmachines/core'

const secrets = createSecretsManager({
  provider: 'aws', // or 'gcp', 'azure'
  region: 'us-east-1',
})

// Access secrets
const apiKey = await secrets.get('api-key')
```

## Monitoring and Logging

### Basic Monitoring

```typescript
import { monitor } from '@deanmachines/core'

monitor.configure({
  metrics: ['cpu', 'memory', 'requests'],
  interval: '1m',
  alerting: {
    threshold: {
      cpu: 80,
      memory: 85,
    },
  },
})
```

### Advanced Observability

```typescript
import { observability } from '@deanmachines/core'

observability.configure({
  tracing: {
    enabled: true,
    sampler: 0.1,
  },
  metrics: {
    custom: {
      'agent.response.time': {
        type: 'histogram',
        buckets: [0.1, 0.5, 1, 2],
      },
    },
  },
  logging: {
    level: 'info',
    format: 'json',
    destination: 'cloudwatch',
  },
})
```

## Best Practices

### Security

- Use environment-specific configurations
- Implement proper access controls
- Encrypt sensitive data
- Regular security audits
- Use secure communication channels

### Performance

- Implement caching strategies
- Use appropriate instance sizes
- Configure auto-scaling properly
- Monitor resource usage
- Optimize database queries

### Reliability

- Implement health checks
- Use multiple availability zones
- Set up proper backup strategies
- Implement retry mechanisms
- Monitor error rates

<Callout type="warning">
  Always test your deployment configuration in a staging environment before deploying to production.
</Callout>

## Advanced Topics

- [Blue-Green Deployments](/docs/advanced-features/blue-green)
- [Canary Releases](/docs/advanced-features/canary)
- [Custom Runtime Configuration](/docs/advanced-features/custom-runtime)
- [Multi-Region Deployment](/docs/advanced-features/multi-region)
````

## File: src/content/docs/core-concepts/memory.mdx
````
---
title: Memory Management
description: Understanding how AI agents maintain context and learn from interactions using the memory system.
---

# Memory Management

The memory system is a fundamental component that enables AI agents to maintain context, learn from interactions, and develop over time.

## Memory Types

### Conversational Memory

Maintains dialogue context and conversation history:

```typescript
import { createMemory } from '@deanmachines/core'

const conversationalMemory = createMemory({
  type: 'conversational',
  ttl: '24h',
  maxItems: 100,
})
```

### Semantic Memory

Stores and retrieves information based on meaning:

```typescript
const semanticMemory = createMemory({
  type: 'semantic',
  embedModel: 'ada-002',
  similarityThreshold: 0.85,
})
```

### Episodic Memory

Records sequences of events and experiences:

```typescript
const episodicMemory = createMemory({
  type: 'episodic',
  timeframe: '7d',
  indexing: 'temporal',
})
```

## Storage Options

### In-Memory Storage

Quick access for temporary data:

```typescript
const volatileMemory = createMemory({
  type: 'conversational',
  storage: {
    type: 'memory',
    maxSize: '1GB',
  },
})
```

### Redis Storage

Distributed storage for scalability:

```typescript
const redisMemory = createMemory({
  type: 'conversational',
  storage: {
    type: 'redis',
    url: process.env.REDIS_URL,
    prefix: 'agent:memory:',
  },
})
```

### Vector Database

For semantic search and similarity matching:

```typescript
const vectorMemory = createMemory({
  type: 'semantic',
  storage: {
    type: 'pinecone',
    apiKey: process.env.PINECONE_API_KEY,
    environment: 'production',
  },
})
```

## Memory Operations

### Writing to Memory

```typescript
// Store a new memory
await memory.store({
  type: 'conversation',
  content: 'User asked about pricing',
  metadata: {
    timestamp: Date.now(),
    topic: 'pricing',
  },
})

// Update existing memory
await memory.update(memoryId, {
  content: 'Updated information',
})
```

### Querying Memory

```typescript
// Retrieve recent memories
const recent = await memory.query({
  timeframe: 'last_hour',
  limit: 10,
})

// Semantic search
const relevant = await memory.search('product features', {
  similarity: 0.8,
  maxResults: 5,
})

// Complex queries
const memories = await memory.query({
  filter: {
    topic: 'technical',
    confidence: { $gt: 0.9 },
  },
  sort: { timestamp: -1 },
})
```

## Memory Management

### Cleanup and Maintenance

```typescript
// Remove old memories
await memory.cleanup({
  olderThan: '30d',
  excludeTypes: ['critical'],
})

// Compact storage
await memory.optimize()
```

### Memory Limitations

```typescript
const limitedMemory = createMemory({
  maxSize: '1GB',
  maxItems: 10000,
  pruning: {
    strategy: 'lru',
    threshold: 0.9,
  },
})
```

## Integration with Agents

### Basic Integration

```typescript
const agent = createAgent({
  name: 'SmartAgent',
  memory: conversationalMemory,
})

agent.onMessage(async (message, context) => {
  // Access memory in handlers
  const history = await context.memory.getRecent()

  // Use memory for response
  return generateResponse(message, history)
})
```

### Advanced Memory Usage

```typescript
const agent = createAgent({
  name: 'AdvancedAgent',
  memory: {
    conversation: conversationalMemory,
    knowledge: semanticMemory,
    experience: episodicMemory,
  },
})

agent.onMessage(async (message, context) => {
  // Access different memory types
  const conversationContext = await context.memory.conversation.getRecent()
  const relevantKnowledge = await context.memory.knowledge.search(message)
  const pastExperiences = await context.memory.experience.getSimilar(message)

  // Combine information for response
  return generateResponse(message, {
    context: conversationContext,
    knowledge: relevantKnowledge,
    experiences: pastExperiences,
  })
})
```

## Best Practices

### Performance Optimization

- Use appropriate TTL values
- Implement efficient indexing
- Cache frequently accessed data
- Use batch operations for bulk updates

### Data Management

- Regular cleanup of old data
- Implement data retention policies
- Monitor storage usage
- Back up critical memories

### Security Considerations

- Encrypt sensitive data
- Implement access controls
- Sanitize inputs
- Regular security audits

<Callout type="warning">
  Memory usage can significantly impact performance and costs. Monitor and optimize memory usage based on your application's needs.
</Callout>

## Advanced Topics

- [Memory Persistence Strategies](/docs/advanced-features/memory-persistence)
- [Custom Storage Backends](/docs/advanced-features/custom-storage)
- [Memory Optimization](/docs/advanced-features/memory-optimization)
- [Distributed Memory Systems](/docs/advanced-features/distributed-memory)
````

## File: src/content/docs/core-concepts/networks.mdx
````
---
title: "Networks"
description: "Understanding the network architecture in DeanMachines"
---

# Networks

## Overview

DeanMachines uses a distributed network architecture to connect and coordinate multiple agents. This section covers the core concepts of networks in DeanMachines.

## Network Types

### Local Network
- Runs on a single machine
- Ideal for development and testing
- Limited scalability

### Distributed Network
- Runs across multiple machines
- Supports horizontal scaling
- Requires proper configuration for high availability

### Cloud Network
- Runs on cloud infrastructure
- Automatic scaling capabilities
- Enterprise-grade security features

## Network Components

### Network Coordinator
- Manages communication between agents
- Handles message routing
- Monitors network health

### Message Bus
- Provides reliable message delivery
- Supports various communication protocols
- Handles message queuing and persistence

### Network Policies
- Defines communication rules
- Controls data flow
- Implements security measures

## Best Practices

1. Use appropriate network type based on your needs
2. Implement proper error handling
3. Monitor network performance
4. Regularly update network configuration
5. Follow security guidelines
````

## File: src/content/docs/core-concepts/overview.mdx
````
---
title: Core Concepts
description: Understanding the fundamental concepts and architecture of deanmachines AI.
---

# Core Concepts

This section covers the fundamental concepts and architecture of deanmachines AI platform. Understanding these concepts will help you build more effective AI solutions.

## Platform Overview

deanmachines AI is built on several key pillars:

- **AI Agents**: Autonomous entities that can perceive, decide, and act
- **Memory Systems**: Sophisticated context management and learning capabilities
- **Deployment Infrastructure**: Cloud-native deployment and scaling solutions
- **Network Orchestration**: Management of agent networks and interactions

## Key Components

### AI Agents

[AI Agents](/docs/core-concepts/agents) are the building blocks of our platform. Each agent can:

- Process and understand natural language
- Maintain context across conversations
- Learn from interactions
- Integrate with external systems

### Memory Management

Our [Memory System](/docs/core-concepts/memory) provides:

- Persistent context storage
- Learning and adaptation capabilities
- State management across sessions
- Flexible storage options

### Deployment Options

The [Deployment](/docs/core-concepts/deployment) system offers:

- Multi-cloud deployment support
- Automatic scaling
- Load balancing
- High availability configurations

### Network Architecture

[Agent Networks](/docs/core-concepts/agent-networks) enable:

- Inter-agent communication
- Task distribution
- Resource sharing
- Coordinated decision making

## System Architecture

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Client Application] --> B[API Gateway]
    B --> C[Agent Network]
    C --> D[Memory System]
    C --> E[Processing Engine]
    D --> F[Storage Layer]
    E --> G[ML Models]
```

## Development Flow

1. **Design**: Plan your AI solution architecture
2. **Build**: Create and configure agents
3. **Test**: Validate behavior and performance
4. **Deploy**: Launch in production environment
5. **Monitor**: Track performance and usage
6. **Iterate**: Improve based on feedback

## Best Practices

- Follow the [Security Guidelines](/docs/security)
- Implement proper [Error Handling](/docs/core-concepts/error-handling)
- Use [Monitoring Tools](/docs/core-concepts/monitoring)
- Structure your [Agent Communication](/docs/core-concepts/agent-communication)

## Further Reading

- [Advanced Features](/docs/advanced-features)
- [API Reference](/docs/api-reference)
- [Example Projects](/docs/examples)

<Callout type="info">
  Each concept has its own detailed documentation page. Use the navigation to explore specific topics in depth.
</Callout>
````

## File: src/content/docs/getting-started/configuration/page.mdx
````
---
title: "Configuration"
description: "Guide to configuring DeanMachines"
---

# Configuration

## Overview

DeanMachines can be configured in multiple ways to suit your needs. This guide will help you understand the different configuration options and how to set them up.

## Configuration Methods

### 1. Configuration File

Create a `deanmachines.config.js` file in your project root:

```javascript
module.exports = {
  // Core settings
  port: 3000,
  environment: 'development',
  logLevel: 'debug',
  
  // Agent settings
  agent: {
    maxConcurrency: 5,
    timeout: 30000,
    retryCount: 3
  },
  
  // Network settings
  network: {
    type: 'local',
    protocol: 'tcp',
    encryption: true
  },
  
  // Deployment settings
  deployment: {
    environment: 'development',
    region: 'us-east-1',
    autoScaling: true
  }
}
```

### 2. Environment Variables

All configuration options can be overridden using environment variables:

```bash
# Core settings
DEANMACHINES_PORT=3000
DEANMACHINES_ENVIRONMENT=production
DEANMACHINES_LOG_LEVEL=info

# Agent settings
DEANMACHINES_AGENT_MAX_CONCURRENCY=5
DEANMACHINES_AGENT_TIMEOUT=30000
DEANMACHINES_AGENT_RETRY_COUNT=3

# Network settings
DEANMACHINES_NETWORK_TYPE=local
DEANMACHINES_NETWORK_PROTOCOL=tcp
DEANMACHINES_NETWORK_ENCRYPTION=true

# Deployment settings
DEANMACHINES_DEPLOYMENT_ENVIRONMENT=production
DEANMACHINES_DEPLOYMENT_REGION=us-east-1
DEANMACHINES_DEPLOYMENT_AUTO_SCALING=true
```

### 3. Command Line Options

Configuration can also be set via command line options:

```bash
deansmachines start --environment production --region us-east-1
```

## Configuration Options

### Core Settings

```javascript
{
  port: number,              // Application port
  environment: string,       // Environment mode (development/production)
  logLevel: string,          // Logging level (debug, info, warn, error)
  timezone: string,          // Timezone for timestamps
  metrics: boolean,          // Enable metrics collection
  telemetry: boolean         // Enable telemetry
}
```

### Agent Settings

```javascript
{
  maxConcurrency: number,    // Maximum concurrent operations
  timeout: number,          // Operation timeout in milliseconds
  retryCount: number,       // Number of retries on failure
  memoryLimit: number,      // Memory limit in MB
  cpuLimit: number          // CPU limit as percentage
}
```

### Network Settings

```javascript
{
  type: string,             // Network type (local, distributed, cloud)
  protocol: string,         // Communication protocol (tcp, udp, etc.)
  encryption: boolean,      // Enable encryption
  compression: boolean,     // Enable compression
  maxConnections: number,   // Maximum concurrent connections
  keepAlive: number        // Keep-alive interval in seconds
}
```

### Deployment Settings

```javascript
{
  environment: string,      // Deployment environment
  region: string,          // Cloud region
  autoScaling: boolean,     // Enable auto-scaling
  minInstances: number,     // Minimum instances
  maxInstances: number,     // Maximum instances
  healthCheck: number,      // Health check interval
  backupInterval: number   // Backup interval in hours
}
```

## Best Practices

1. **Keep Sensitive Data Secure**
   - Use environment variables for API keys and secrets
   - Never commit sensitive data to version control
   - Use encrypted configuration files when possible

2. **Environment-Specific Configurations**
   - Use different configuration files for different environments
   - Keep development and production configurations separate
   - Use environment variables to override sensitive settings

3. **Documentation**
   - Document all custom configurations
   - Keep a changelog of configuration changes
   - Review configurations regularly

4. **Validation**
   - Validate configuration before deployment
   - Use configuration management tools
   - Implement configuration versioning

5. **Monitoring**
   - Monitor configuration changes
   - Track configuration usage
   - Alert on configuration errors

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

1. **Configuration Not Applied**
   - Check file permissions
   - Verify configuration file location
   - Check environment variable precedence

2. **Invalid Configuration**
   - Validate configuration syntax
   - Check type compatibility
   - Verify required fields

3. **Environment Variables Not Found**
   - Check environment variable names
   - Verify variable existence
   - Check variable scope

## Migration Guide

When upgrading to a new version:

1. Review release notes for configuration changes
2. Update configuration files
3. Test new configuration
4. Document changes
5. Backup old configuration

## Security Considerations

1. Never store sensitive data in plain text
2. Use encrypted configuration storage
3. Implement proper access controls
4. Regularly audit configuration access
5. Use secure configuration management tools
````

## File: src/content/docs/guides/memory-management.mdx
````
---
title: Memory Management
description: Learn how to effectively manage memory in deanmachines AI agents.
---

# Memory Management Guide

Learn best practices for managing memory in your AI agents to improve performance and reliability.

## Types of Memory

### Short-Term Memory

Short-term memory is used for temporary storage during agent interactions:

```typescript
import { ShortTermMemory } from '@deanmachines/core'

const shortTermMemory = new ShortTermMemory({
  capacity: 1000,       // Maximum number of items
  ttl: '30m',          // Time-to-live
  strategy: 'lru',     // Least Recently Used eviction
  compression: true    // Enable compression
})
```

### Long-Term Memory

Long-term memory persists important information across sessions:

```typescript
import { LongTermMemory } from '@deanmachines/core'

const longTermMemory = new LongTermMemory({
  storage: {
    type: 'postgres',
    connection: process.env.DATABASE_URL,
    tableName: 'agent_memory'
  },
  indexing: {
    enabled: true,
    type: 'vector',
    dimensions: 1536
  }
})
```

## Memory Operations

### Storing Information

```typescript
interface MemoryEntry {
  key: string
  value: unknown
  context?: Record<string, unknown>
  importance?: number
  tags?: string[]
}

await memory.store({
  key: 'user_preference',
  value: {
    theme: 'dark',
    language: 'en'
  },
  context: {
    userId: 'user123',
    timestamp: Date.now()
  },
  importance: 0.8,
  tags: ['preferences', 'ui']
})
```

### Retrieving Information

```typescript
// Direct key lookup
const preference = await memory.retrieve('user_preference')

// Query by tags
const allPreferences = await memory.queryByTags(['preferences'])

// Semantic search
const similarMemories = await memory.searchSimilar(
  'user interface settings',
  { limit: 5, threshold: 0.7 }
)
```

## Memory Management Strategies

### Cleanup and Optimization

```typescript
interface CleanupConfig {
  olderThan: string
  importance: number
  dryRun?: boolean
}

// Remove old, low-importance memories
await memory.cleanup({
  olderThan: '30d',
  importance: 0.3,
  dryRun: true  // Preview what would be removed
})

// Optimize storage
await memory.optimize({
  vacuum: true,
  reindex: true
})
```

### Memory Monitoring

```typescript
// Get memory usage statistics
const stats = await memory.getStats()
// {
//   totalEntries: 10000,
//   totalSize: '500MB',
//   avgAccessTime: '50ms',
//   hitRate: 0.95
// }

// Set up monitoring alerts
memory.on('capacity-warning', async (usage) => {
  if (usage > 0.9) {  // 90% capacity
    await memory.cleanup({ importance: 0.2 })
  }
})
```

## Best Practices

1. **Memory Segmentation**
   - Separate short-term and long-term memory
   - Use appropriate storage backends
   - Implement proper TTL values
   - Consider memory hierarchies

2. **Performance Optimization**
   - Enable compression for large datasets
   - Index frequently accessed data
   - Implement caching strategies
   - Monitor memory usage

3. **Data Management**
   - Regular cleanup of stale data
   - Implement importance scoring
   - Use appropriate retention policies
   - Back up critical memories

<Callout type="warning">
  Always validate and sanitize data before storing in memory to prevent security issues.
</Callout>

## Error Handling

```typescript
try {
  await memory.store(entry)
} catch (error) {
  if (error instanceof MemoryCapacityError) {
    await memory.cleanup({ importance: 0.3 })
    await memory.store(entry)
  } else if (error instanceof StorageError) {
    // Handle storage backend issues
    await memory.reconnect()
  }
  throw error
}
```

## Next Steps

- [Network Architecture Guide](/docs/guides/network-architecture)
- [Performance Optimization](/docs/guides/performance)
- [Memory API Reference](/docs/api-reference/memory)
````

## File: src/content/docs/guides/monitoring.mdx
````
---
title: Monitoring & Observability
description: Learn how to monitor, log, and observe your AI applications effectively.
---

# Monitoring & Observability

Learn how to implement comprehensive monitoring and observability for your deanmachines AI applications.

## Metrics Collection

### Agent Metrics

```typescript
import { Metrics } from "@deanmachines/monitoring"

const metrics = new Metrics({
  agent: {
    responseTime: true,
    memoryUsage: true,
    throughput: true,
    errorRate: true,
  },
  customMetrics: {
    "agent.decisions": {
      type: "counter",
      help: "Number of decisions made by the agent",
    },
  },
})

agent.use(metrics)
```

### Performance Monitoring

```typescript
const performanceConfig = {
  metrics: ["cpu", "memory", "latency"],
  alerts: {
    cpu: { threshold: 80, window: "5m" },
    memory: { threshold: 85, window: "5m" },
    latency: { threshold: 1000, window: "1m" },
  },
}
```

## Logging

### Structured Logging

```typescript
import { Logger } from "@deanmachines/core"

const logger = new Logger({
  level: "info",
  format: "json",
  metadata: {
    service: "agent-service",
    environment: process.env.NODE_ENV,
  },
})

agent.onMessage(async (message) => {
  logger.info("Processing message", {
    messageId: message.id,
    type: message.type,
    timestamp: new Date().toISOString(),
  })
})
```

### Log Levels

- **ERROR**: Errors that need immediate attention
- **WARN**: Potential issues or degraded performance
- **INFO**: Normal operation events
- **DEBUG**: Detailed debugging information
- **TRACE**: Very detailed flow information

## Tracing

### Distributed Tracing

```typescript
import { Tracer } from "@deanmachines/monitoring"

const tracer = new Tracer({
  serviceName: "agent-service",
  samplingRate: 0.1,
  exporters: ["jaeger", "zipkin"],
})

agent.use(tracer)
```

### Span Management

```typescript
async function processRequest(req) {
  const span = tracer.startSpan("process-request")
  try {
    // Add context to span
    span.setAttributes({
      "request.id": req.id,
      "request.type": req.type,
    })

    const result = await handleRequest(req)
    span.end()
    return result
  } catch (error) {
    span.setStatus("error")
    span.recordException(error)
    span.end()
    throw error
  }
}
```

## Alerting

### Alert Configuration

```typescript
const alertConfig = {
  channels: ["email", "slack", "pagerduty"],
  rules: [
    {
      name: "high-error-rate",
      condition: "error_rate > 0.05",
      duration: "5m",
      severity: "critical",
      notifications: ["slack", "pagerduty"],
    },
    {
      name: "memory-warning",
      condition: "memory_usage > 80",
      duration: "10m",
      severity: "warning",
      notifications: ["email", "slack"],
    },
  ],
}
```

### Alert Management

- Set up escalation policies
- Define on-call rotations
- Configure alert routing rules
- Implement alert grouping

## Dashboard Creation

### Metrics Dashboard

```typescript
const dashboardConfig = {
  panels: [
    {
      title: "Agent Response Time",
      metric: "agent_response_time",
      type: "line",
      duration: "24h",
    },
    {
      title: "Memory Usage",
      metric: "memory_usage_bytes",
      type: "gauge",
      thresholds: [
        { value: 70, color: "yellow" },
        { value: 85, color: "red" },
      ],
    },
  ],
}
```

### Custom Visualizations

- Response time distributions
- Error rate trends
- Resource utilization
- Agent interaction patterns

## Best Practices

1. **Data Retention**
   - Define retention policies
   - Implement data aggregation
   - Use appropriate storage solutions

2. **Performance Impact**
   - Monitor the monitoring overhead
   - Use sampling when appropriate
   - Optimize metric collection

3. **Alert Fatigue**
   - Tune alert thresholds carefully
   - Implement alert deduplication
   - Use alert severity levels effectively

4. **Documentation**
   - Document monitoring setup
   - Maintain runbooks
   - Keep dashboards updated

<Callout type="info">
  Regular review and adjustment of monitoring thresholds is essential for maintaining effective observability.
</Callout>

## Next Steps

- [Scaling Strategies](/docs/guides/scaling)
- [Performance Optimization](/docs/guides/performance)
- [Troubleshooting Guide](/docs/guides/troubleshooting)
````

## File: src/content/docs/guides/network-architecture.mdx
````
---
title: Network Architecture
description: Design and implement scalable AI agent networks with deanmachines.
---

# Network Architecture Guide

Learn how to design and implement scalable networks of cooperating AI agents.

## Network Topologies

### Mesh Network

Fully connected agents for maximum collaboration:

```typescript
import { AgentNetwork, NetworkTopology } from '@deanmachines/core'

const meshNetwork = new AgentNetwork({
  topology: NetworkTopology.MESH,
  agents: ['analyst', 'researcher', 'writer'],
  config: {
    fullConnection: true,
    redundancy: true,
    maxLatency: '100ms'
  }
})
```

### Hierarchical Network

Organized hierarchy for complex workflows:

```typescript
interface HierarchicalConfig {
  layers: {
    name: string
    agents: string[]
    connections: {
      up?: string[]
      down?: string[]
    }
  }[]
}

const hierarchicalNetwork = new AgentNetwork({
  topology: NetworkTopology.HIERARCHICAL,
  config: {
    layers: [
      {
        name: 'supervisors',
        agents: ['coordinator', 'planner'],
        connections: {
          down: ['workers']
        }
      },
      {
        name: 'workers',
        agents: ['researcher1', 'researcher2', 'analyst1'],
        connections: {
          up: ['supervisors'],
          down: ['specialists']
        }
      }
    ]
  }
})
```

## Communication Patterns

### Message Routing

```typescript
interface NetworkMessage {
  from: string
  to: string | string[]
  content: unknown
  metadata: {
    priority: number
    ttl: string
    trace?: string
  }
}

// Direct message
await network.sendMessage({
  from: 'analyst',
  to: 'researcher',
  content: {
    type: 'research_request',
    query: 'market analysis 2024'
  },
  metadata: {
    priority: 1,
    ttl: '30s'
  }
})

// Broadcast to layer
await network.broadcastToLayer('workers', {
  from: 'coordinator',
  content: {
    type: 'task_assignment',
    deadline: '2h'
  }
})
```

## Network Monitoring

### Health Checks

```typescript
interface HealthCheckConfig {
  interval: string
  timeout: string
  thresholds: {
    latency: number
    errorRate: number
    messageQueue: number
  }
}

await network.configureHealthChecks({
  interval: '30s',
  timeout: '5s',
  thresholds: {
    latency: 200,    // ms
    errorRate: 0.01,  // 1%
    messageQueue: 100 // max queued messages
  }
})
```

### Performance Metrics

```typescript
// Monitor network performance
network.on('metrics', (metrics) => {
  const {
    messageCount,
    avgLatency,
    errorRate,
    agentUtilization
  } = metrics

  if (avgLatency > 200) {
    network.optimizeRouting()
  }
})
```

## Scaling Strategies

### Dynamic Scaling

```typescript
interface ScalingConfig {
  metrics: ('load' | 'latency' | 'queue')[]
  thresholds: {
    scaleUp: Record<string, number>
    scaleDown: Record<string, number>
  }
  cooldown: {
    up: string
    down: string
  }
}

await network.configureScaling({
  metrics: ['load', 'latency', 'queue'],
  thresholds: {
    scaleUp: {
      load: 80,      // 80% CPU
      latency: 200,  // 200ms
      queue: 100     // 100 messages
    },
    scaleDown: {
      load: 30,
      latency: 50,
      queue: 10
    }
  },
  cooldown: {
    up: '5m',
    down: '15m'
  }
})
```

## Error Handling

### Network Resilience

```typescript
interface ResilienceConfig {
  retry: {
    attempts: number
    backoff: {
      initial: number
      multiplier: number
      max: number
    }
  }
  circuit: {
    threshold: number
    timeout: string
  }
  fallback: {
    enabled: boolean
    strategy: 'cache' | 'alternative' | 'degraded'
  }
}

await network.configureResilience({
  retry: {
    attempts: 3,
    backoff: {
      initial: 1000,
      multiplier: 2,
      max: 10000
    }
  },
  circuit: {
    threshold: 0.5,  // 50% failure rate
    timeout: '30s'   // Time before retry
  },
  fallback: {
    enabled: true,
    strategy: 'degraded'
  }
})
```

## Best Practices

1. **Network Design**
   - Choose appropriate topology
   - Plan for scalability
   - Implement proper error handling
   - Monitor network health

2. **Communication**
   - Use efficient protocols
   - Implement message priorities
   - Handle timeouts properly
   - Enable message tracing

3. **Security**
   - Encrypt network traffic
   - Authenticate agents
   - Monitor for anomalies
   - Regular security audits

<Callout type="warning">
  Always implement proper error handling and recovery mechanisms in distributed networks.
</Callout>

## Next Steps

- [Performance Optimization](/docs/guides/performance)
- [Security Best Practices](/docs/guides/security)
- [Network API Reference](/docs/api-reference/network)
````

# Guides Overview

Welcome to the deanmachines AI guides. These comprehensive guides will help you build, deploy, and maintain your AI applications effectively.

## Getting Started Guides

<div className="grid sm:grid-cols-2 gap-4 mt-6">

  Get up and running with deanmachines AI in minutes.
</Card>

  Learn how to manage agent memory effectively.
</Card>

  Design scalable agent networks.
</Card>

  Secure your AI applications.
</Card>

</div>

  ### Performance Optimization
  Optimize your AI applications for speed and efficiency.
</Card>

  ### Performance Testing
  Comprehensive testing strategies for AI systems.
</Card>

  ### Cost Optimization
  Optimize resource usage and costs.
</Card>

  Build resilient AI systems.
</Card>

</div>

## Development Workflows

<div className="grid sm:grid-cols-2 gap-4 mt-6">

  ### CI/CD Integration
  Automate your deployment pipeline.
</Card>

<Card href="/docs/guides/monitoring">
  ### Monitoring & Observability
  Monitor your AI applications effectively.
</Card>

  ### Troubleshooting
  Debug and resolve common issues.
</Card>

<Card href="/docs/guides/compliance">
  ### Compliance
  Meet regulatory requirements.
</Card>

</div>

## Best Practices

Here are some key best practices to follow when building with deanmachines AI:

1. **Architecture Design**
   - Plan your agent network topology
   - Design for scalability from the start
   - Implement proper error handling
   - Use appropriate memory strategies

2. **Security**
   - Follow security best practices
   - Implement proper authentication
   - Secure sensitive data
   - Regular security audits

3. **Performance**
   - Optimize agent interactions
   - Monitor system resources
   - Implement caching strategies
   - Regular performance testing

4. **Maintenance**
   - Keep dependencies updated
   - Regular backups
   - Monitor system health
   - Document everything

### Development
- Setting up development environments
- Writing efficient agent code
- Testing and validation

- Production deployment strategies

- Troubleshooting

</Callout>
